summary: The later Critical Role runs tonight, the more likely it is I'm going to pull an all-nighter leading into the day that...
body: The later Critical Role runs tonight, the more likely it is I’m going to pull an all-nighter leading into the day that @triplethreattriplets come visit. But luckily!!! Critical Role is Fine!!!! So there’s no reason it might run long tonight!!!!!!

reblog.comment: The later Critical Role runs tonight, the more likely it is I’m going to pull an all-nighter leading into the day that @triplethreattriplets come visit. But luckily!!! Critical Role is Fine!!!! So there’s no reason it might run long tonight!!!!!!

trail.content_raw: The later Critical Role runs tonight, the more likely it is I’m going to pull an all-nighter leading into the day that @triplethreattriplets come visit. But luckily!!! Critical Role is Fine!!!! So there’s no reason it might run long tonight!!!!!!
trail.content: The later Critical Role runs tonight, the more likely it is I’m going to pull an all-nighter leading into the day that @triplethreattriplets come visit. But luckily!!! Critical Role is Fine!!!! So there’s no reason it might run long tonight!!!!!!

summary:
Critical Role, Campaign 1, Episode 26: Vox Machina disguise themselves as flying cows and chase after a giant bird.
Critical...
body:
Critical Role, Campaign 1, Episode 26: Vox Machina disguise themselves as flying cows and chase after a giant bird.
Critical Role, Campaign 2, Episode 26: The Mighty Nein fight a group of slavers on their way to rescue their kidnapped friends; Mollymauk fucking dies.

blog.name: tridecopus
blog.title: It's fine...
blog.description: Fake Geek Boy with low enough self esteem his kink is Actual Geek Boys (TM) explaining why he's not an actual fan. This 26 year old gay cismale fatty enjoys reading trashy novels and various podcasts such as The Adventure Zone, Tomefoolery, and Oh No Ross and Carrie, and hopes to one day be a 2nd husband, and reasonably understands the decision when he's left for the 3rd husband. Is a mediocre D&D DM, because he is the only one in the group with no life. The Ross if you will.

blog.name: beccatoria
blog.title: KABOOM
blog.description: <-- This is not a ninja.

tags: the greatest game of yes and...
own your games you beautiful rascals
summary: So like, a Thing happened on Critical Role.  I’d like to talk about it in...critical terms?  I’m not sure that’s the right...
body:
So like, a Thing happened on Critical Role.  I’d like to talk about it in…critical terms?  I’m not sure that’s the right word.  Listen, my point is mostly that there’s this dogma in a lot of tabletop RPGs that if there’s no chance of dying, there’s no “stakes”.  Nothing matters, nothing feels real, no one invests.  

But I think that depends on why you play the game.  If it’s for strategy, then a loss condition like death makes sense.  If it’s for the story, then why the hell would I invest in a story which might be cut short at any moment, in a narrativly unsatisfying way?

I’ve seen critique from indie circles that D&D needs more failure conditions that aren’t death, but fuck it, those are all just story-based things and that’s down to your DM anyway.  I don’t think that’s a problem with the rules.  It’s absolutely a good maxim for a story-based game, though.  

Because death is absolutely not the worst thing you can do to me as a player.  That’s frustrating and upsetting on a meta level, sure.  But stakes for a character? I mean, it’s the Superman thing again.  You have two schools of thought, right?  “He can’t be hurt, so what are the stakes?” and “He’s invulnerable, but nothing he loves or cares about is, how will he keep it safe?”

Listen, death SHOULD always be on the cards for characters where that makes sense for the end of their story.  It would have made sense for Percy after he completed his revenge.  I understand why Taliesin put very stringent requirements on the resurrection working.  It would have been a very different story, but a good one.  It made sense for Vax at the end of the campaign, and honestly, I’m glad Scanlan didn’t have that wish - that would have felt cheap.  Again - this was an approach agreed between Matt and Liam because they felt it fit with both the world and the character.  It was very sad, but it made sense. If Keyleth had actually died jumping off a cliff? Would that have been fun? Would that have made sense, or been satisfying?  For some people, sure.  But for me? I don’t really think permadeath should have been on the table at that point. 

I’m not here to say that the Critical Role guys are doing it wrong.  They are very clearly doing it very right.  They are playing the game exactly as they want to and it’s fun to watch because they love it.  

We don’t all have to play exactly the way they do, though. To be clear, I don’t think Mercer & Co have ever suggested that either.  The opposite, in fact.  I do think fandom sometimes holds them in such high regard that to question their approach is…not really considered.  

It should be, though? I don’t think the gift of the show is an example to follow, I think it’s a common example we can use as a reference point while we work out what we want from our games.  

Death-averse players, I see you.  There ain’t nothing wrong with you or your style, and it doesn’t mean you’re lightweight or your stories are less epic.  

The character I played for the longest time - ten years of my life - she had a fling with another character’s best friend.  He was easy going, kind, a paladin.  Thing is, this one time, she almost died.  And by almost, I mean, by the rules, she did die.  Except this devil saved her for some reason.  And then she pissed off that devil by refusing to acknowledge the debt.  And then the devil kidnapped the dude.  Classic shit.  

“I shall rescue him!” I declared, convinced that I’d fix everything. I schemed a good scheme.  It involved a world-changing secret, a high-class auction and a priest in an enormous hat.  Anyway, I got my boy back and he was broken.  Time moves differently in hell.  The weeks I’d taken to steal him away again had been years for him.  He’d lost his faith.  He regretted ever meeting me. I did my best to help him rebuild parts of his life.  But it was always awkward.  Mostly we just avoided each other.  One day, I had to choose between him and another volunteer - which one would undertake a mission that would quite possibly result in their deaths. I chose him. In part - awfully and selfishly - because I figured I might as well pour my mistakes into a single vessel.  And yes, he died.

Later, much much later, I found out the devil who stole him was me from a possible future.  That’s why she saved me: to protect her own genesis.  

Or.  

Another player in another campaign. He left his childhood faith (the sun god of a dragon pantheon).  Not out of bitterness, but just because he realised it was chosen for him, he never committed himself, and it felt dishonest.  It left him worried, though: what would happen to his soul when he died? Adventures ensued, he became a knight of the Winter Court under Oberon, the Faerie King.  He rode with the Wild Hunt.  Eventually, something killed him. We resurrected him and he was so happy.  He’d learned his afterlife was with the Court - his soul would join the endless feast of fallen knights; chaos and magic and laughter forever.  It was an affirmative, positive experience.  A death that alleviated his fear of death. 

Then he died again.  He’d become overconfident and unworried.  He died fighting the chosen warriors of Lolth, a spider goddess of evil and greed.  This time he didn’t wake up in the Winter Court. He woke up facing the Dragon of Judgement, from his original, abandoned childhood pantheon.  It was explained to him that this god retained the right to judge the souls of all who left the faith.  King Oberon acknowledged this right, and so, with an infinite number of souls to judge, the dragon god had allowed this soul to go on its way - to be judged one day, before the end times.  But Lolth is jealous, she acknowledges no rights other than her own. Killed by one of her priests, she tried to consume my friend’s soul before any such judgement could occur. So the Dragon took him and saved him, but he found himself having to argue his own moral worth to an impassive deity he had abandoned. A deity who made some unsettling points about some of his recent actions and choices.

Or.  

When another player’s fuckup sister got herself killed.  We laughed.  Ah, classic Anna.  We were rich and powerful.  We’d fix this in no time.  Except someone very powerful had trapped her soul.  We panicked.  And we got her back eventually, but it took a long, difficult voyage through a magical void in a crystal ship and a lot of dead vampires to do it.  

Let’s bring this back to Molly and Critical Role. Arguably, of all the characters that have ever been on this show, Molly is the one for whom it makes the most sense to return from the dead, in some form, as someone. Again, in the current climate, I gotta stress that I’m not trying to second guess Matt and Taliesin’s decisions about their game. But using this event as a framework through which to discuss my preferences, it’s a really good illustration of why I’m not a fan of this approach to player death.  

I feel like it boxes you in.  At a certain point there’s this external pressure to have a death “stick”.  To prove that the grief and the stress of these possible-deaths isn’t unwarranted.  To prove that all the talk about death needing to be a possibility wasn’t just talk.  So either a character comes back, and proves that the grief and fear around player character death is just…turgid bullshit, or a character doesn’t come back and then…is that because it’s best for the story?  For the fun of the group?  For the overall narrative?  Or is it in arbitrary adherence to some idea of “stakes”?  

This is a fantasy game full of magic and chaos and heroism.  Death can have so many meanings - so many more than “your story ends”.  

If you like the stakes being the end of the story, that’s fine. Some of you are gamblers first, and I tip my hat to you.  

But if you’re like me - if you want to star in a story, and you want to know that story will have a…fitting ending - I see you.  

It’s possible to embrace D&D’s revolving door of mortality and do wonderful things.  We should talk about those options more, I think.  So much effort goes into talking about how to handle PC deaths.  We should put at least some into how to resurrect them without it becoming banal.

In the greatest game of “Yes, and…”, why does that stop with your life? 

Yes.  Yes you died.  Yes, you died, and then.

Because death is absolutely not the worst thing you can do to me as a player.  That’s frustrating and upsetting on a meta level, sure.  But stakes for a character? I mean, it’s the Superman thing again.  You have two schools of thought, right?  “He can’t be hurt, so what are the stakes?” and “He’s invulnerable, but nothing he loves or cares about is, how will he keep it safe?”

Listen, death SHOULD always be on the cards for characters where that makes sense for the end of their story.  It would have made sense for Percy after he completed his revenge.  I understand why Taliesin put very stringent requirements on the resurrection working.  It would have been a very different story, but a good one.  It made sense for Vax at the end of the campaign, and honestly, I’m glad Scanlan didn’t have that wish - that would have felt cheap.  Again - this was an approach agreed between Matt and Liam because they felt it fit with both the world and the character.  It was very sad, but it made sense. If Keyleth had actually died jumping off a cliff? Would that have been fun? Would that have made sense, or been satisfying?  For some people, sure.  But for me? I don’t really think permadeath should have been on the table at that point. 

I’m not here to say that the Critical Role guys are doing it wrong.  They are very clearly doing it very right.  They are playing the game exactly as they want to and it’s fun to watch because they love it.  

We don’t all have to play exactly the way they do, though. To be clear, I don’t think Mercer & Co have ever suggested that either.  The opposite, in fact.  I do think fandom sometimes holds them in such high regard that to question their approach is…not really considered.  

It should be, though? I don’t think the gift of the show is an example to follow, I think it’s a common example we can use as a reference point while we work out what we want from our games.  

Death-averse players, I see you.  There ain’t nothing wrong with you or your style, and it doesn’t mean you’re lightweight or your stories are less epic.  

The character I played for the longest time - ten years of my life - she had a fling with another character’s best friend.  He was easy going, kind, a paladin.  Thing is, this one time, she almost died.  And by almost, I mean, by the rules, she did die.  Except this devil saved her for some reason.  And then she pissed off that devil by refusing to acknowledge the debt.  And then the devil kidnapped the dude.  Classic shit.  

“I shall rescue him!” I declared, convinced that I’d fix everything. I schemed a good scheme.  It involved a world-changing secret, a high-class auction and a priest in an enormous hat.  Anyway, I got my boy back and he was broken.  Time moves differently in hell.  The weeks I’d taken to steal him away again had been years for him.  He’d lost his faith.  He regretted ever meeting me. I did my best to help him rebuild parts of his life.  But it was always awkward.  Mostly we just avoided each other.  One day, I had to choose between him and another volunteer - which one would undertake a mission that would quite possibly result in their deaths. I chose him. In part - awfully and selfishly - because I figured I might as well pour my mistakes into a single vessel.  And yes, he died.

Later, much much later, I found out the devil who stole him was me from a possible future.  That’s why she saved me: to protect her own genesis.  

Or.  

Another player in another campaign. He left his childhood faith (the sun god of a dragon pantheon).  Not out of bitterness, but just because he realised it was chosen for him, he never committed himself, and it felt dishonest.  It left him worried, though: what would happen to his soul when he died? Adventures ensued, he became a knight of the Winter Court under Oberon, the Faerie King.  He rode with the Wild Hunt.  Eventually, something killed him. We resurrected him and he was so happy.  He’d learned his afterlife was with the Court - his soul would join the endless feast of fallen knights; chaos and magic and laughter forever.  It was an affirmative, positive experience.  A death that alleviated his fear of death. 

Then he died again.  He’d become overconfident and unworried.  He died fighting the chosen warriors of Lolth, a spider goddess of evil and greed.  This time he didn’t wake up in the Winter Court. He woke up facing the Dragon of Judgement, from his original, abandoned childhood pantheon.  It was explained to him that this god retained the right to judge the souls of all who left the faith.  King Oberon acknowledged this right, and so, with an infinite number of souls to judge, the dragon god had allowed this soul to go on its way - to be judged one day, before the end times.  But Lolth is jealous, she acknowledges no rights other than her own. Killed by one of her priests, she tried to consume my friend’s soul before any such judgement could occur. So the Dragon took him and saved him, but he found himself having to argue his own moral worth to an impassive deity he had abandoned. A deity who made some unsettling points about some of his recent actions and choices.

Or.  

When another player’s fuckup sister got herself killed.  We laughed.  Ah, classic Anna.  We were rich and powerful.  We’d fix this in no time.  Except someone very powerful had trapped her soul.  We panicked.  And we got her back eventually, but it took a long, difficult voyage through a magical void in a crystal ship and a lot of dead vampires to do it.  

Let’s bring this back to Molly and Critical Role. Arguably, of all the characters that have ever been on this show, Molly is the one for whom it makes the most sense to return from the dead, in some form, as someone. Again, in the current climate, I gotta stress that I’m not trying to second guess Matt and Taliesin’s decisions about their game. But using this event as a framework through which to discuss my preferences, it’s a really good illustration of why I’m not a fan of this approach to player death.  

I feel like it boxes you in.  At a certain point there’s this external pressure to have a death “stick”.  To prove that the grief and the stress of these possible-deaths isn’t unwarranted.  To prove that all the talk about death needing to be a possibility wasn’t just talk.  So either a character comes back, and proves that the grief and fear around player character death is just…turgid bullshit, or a character doesn’t come back and then…is that because it’s best for the story?  For the fun of the group?  For the overall narrative?  Or is it in arbitrary adherence to some idea of “stakes”?  

This is a fantasy game full of magic and chaos and heroism.  Death can have so many meanings - so many more than “your story ends”.  

If you like the stakes being the end of the story, that’s fine. Some of you are gamblers first, and I tip my hat to you.  

But if you’re like me - if you want to star in a story, and you want to know that story will have a…fitting ending - I see you.  

It’s possible to embrace D&D’s revolving door of mortality and do wonderful things.  We should talk about those options more, I think.  So much effort goes into talking about how to handle PC deaths.  We should put at least some into how to resurrect them without it becoming banal.

In the greatest game of “Yes, and…”, why does that stop with your life? 

Yes.  Yes you died.  Yes, you died, and then.
trail.content:
So like, a Thing happened on Critical Role.  I’d like to talk about it in…critical terms?  I’m not sure that’s the right word.  Listen, my point is mostly that there’s this dogma in a lot of tabletop RPGs that if there’s no chance of dying, there’s no “stakes”.  Nothing matters, nothing feels real, no one invests.  

But I think that depends on why you play the game.  If it’s for strategy, then a loss condition like death makes sense.  If it’s for the story, then why the hell would I invest in a story which might be cut short at any moment, in a narrativly unsatisfying way?

I’ve seen critique from indie circles that D&D needs more failure conditions that aren’t death, but fuck it, those are all just story-based things and that’s down to your DM anyway.  I don’t think that’s a problem with the rules.  It’s absolutely a good maxim for a story-based game, though.  

Because death is absolutely not the worst thing you can do to me as a player.  That’s frustrating and upsetting on a meta level, sure.  But stakes for a character? I mean, it’s the Superman thing again.  You have two schools of thought, right?  “He can’t be hurt, so what are the stakes?” and “He’s invulnerable, but nothing he loves or cares about is, how will he keep it safe?”

Listen, death SHOULD always be on the cards for characters where that makes sense for the end of their story.  It would have made sense for Percy after he completed his revenge.  I understand why Taliesin put very stringent requirements on the resurrection working.  It would have been a very different story, but a good one.  It made sense for Vax at the end of the campaign, and honestly, I’m glad Scanlan didn’t have that wish - that would have felt cheap.  Again - this was an approach agreed between Matt and Liam because they felt it fit with both the world and the character.  It was very sad, but it made sense. If Keyleth had actually died jumping off a cliff? Would that have been fun? Would that have made sense, or been satisfying?  For some people, sure.  But for me? I don’t really think permadeath should have been on the table at that point. 

I’m not here to say that the Critical Role guys are doing it wrong.  They are very clearly doing it very right.  They are playing the game exactly as they want to and it’s fun to watch because they love it.  

We don’t all have to play exactly the way they do, though. To be clear, I don’t think Mercer & Co have ever suggested that either.  The opposite, in fact.  I do think fandom sometimes holds them in such high regard that to question their approach is…not really considered.  

It should be, though? I don’t think the gift of the show is an example to follow, I think it’s a common example we can use as a reference point while we work out what we want from our games.  

Death-averse players, I see you.  There ain’t nothing wrong with you or your style, and it doesn’t mean you’re lightweight or your stories are less epic.  

The character I played for the longest time - ten years of my life - she had a fling with another character’s best friend.  He was easy going, kind, a paladin.  Thing is, this one time, she almost died.  And by almost, I mean, by the rules, she did die.  Except this devil saved her for some reason.  And then she pissed off that devil by refusing to acknowledge the debt.  And then the devil kidnapped the dude.  Classic shit.  

“I shall rescue him!” I declared, convinced that I’d fix everything. I schemed a good scheme.  It involved a world-changing secret, a high-class auction and a priest in an enormous hat.  Anyway, I got my boy back and he was broken.  Time moves differently in hell.  The weeks I’d taken to steal him away again had been years for him.  He’d lost his faith.  He regretted ever meeting me. I did my best to help him rebuild parts of his life.  But it was always awkward.  Mostly we just avoided each other.  One day, I had to choose between him and another volunteer - which one would undertake a mission that would quite possibly result in their deaths. I chose him. In part - awfully and selfishly - because I figured I might as well pour my mistakes into a single vessel.  And yes, he died.

Later, much much later, I found out the devil who stole him was me from a possible future.  That’s why she saved me: to protect her own genesis.  

Or.  

Another player in another campaign. He left his childhood faith (the sun god of a dragon pantheon).  Not out of bitterness, but just because he realised it was chosen for him, he never committed himself, and it felt dishonest.  It left him worried, though: what would happen to his soul when he died? Adventures ensued, he became a knight of the Winter Court under Oberon, the Faerie King.  He rode with the Wild Hunt.  Eventually, something killed him. We resurrected him and he was so happy.  He’d learned his afterlife was with the Court - his soul would join the endless feast of fallen knights; chaos and magic and laughter forever.  It was an affirmative, positive experience.  A death that alleviated his fear of death. 

Then he died again.  He’d become overconfident and unworried.  He died fighting the chosen warriors of Lolth, a spider goddess of evil and greed.  This time he didn’t wake up in the Winter Court. He woke up facing the Dragon of Judgement, from his original, abandoned childhood pantheon.  It was explained to him that this god retained the right to judge the souls of all who left the faith.  King Oberon acknowledged this right, and so, with an infinite number of souls to judge, the dragon god had allowed this soul to go on its way - to be judged one day, before the end times.  But Lolth is jealous, she acknowledges no rights other than her own. Killed by one of her priests, she tried to consume my friend’s soul before any such judgement could occur. So the Dragon took him and saved him, but he found himself having to argue his own moral worth to an impassive deity he had abandoned. A deity who made some unsettling points about some of his recent actions and choices.

Or.  

When another player’s fuckup sister got herself killed.  We laughed.  Ah, classic Anna.  We were rich and powerful.  We’d fix this in no time.  Except someone very powerful had trapped her soul.  We panicked.  And we got her back eventually, but it took a long, difficult voyage through a magical void in a crystal ship and a lot of dead vampires to do it.  

Let’s bring this back to Molly and Critical Role. Arguably, of all the characters that have ever been on this show, Molly is the one for whom it makes the most sense to return from the dead, in some form, as someone. Again, in the current climate, I gotta stress that I’m not trying to second guess Matt and Taliesin’s decisions about their game. But using this event as a framework through which to discuss my preferences, it’s a really good illustration of why I’m not a fan of this approach to player death.

summary: Post-Iron Shepherd Battle Options
title: Post-Iron Shepherd Battle Options
body:
Thanks to @LornArt_ for this art piece!

Following their first encounter with the Iron Shepherds, the Mighty Nein find themselves with new trials and difficulties ahead of them. In particular, there is one tribulation the party can approach in multiple ways. Ask not for whom Jester’s bell tolls…

Read More

blog.name: chailattemusings
blog.title: Chai Latte Musings
blog.description: Hello! I'm Chai, genderfluid, they/them or per/pers. Bisexual, panromantic, grey-ace. My main fandom is Critical Role with splashes of other media. Follow me on Twitter @chailattemusing. My tumblr icon was done by catatodraws.

summary: pinprick
title: pinprick
body:
I wrote a little stream-of-consciousness thing for Molly. 

Warnings: death, obviously. also blood imagery. 

words: ~800

–

Death is a pinprick. It pierces the heart to bleed slow, rips out life in tiny imperceptible threads that leave them strung up and torn up and waiting for the end. It doesn’t matter how fast it is–the infinity of a moment stretches like a shadow at sunset, pulled to the horizon where the end is blurred and unreachable, beyond the grasp of reality and vanishing past the sky.

It bleeds. Long beyond the point of death, it bleeds. One strike and the river runs pure down the bodies of friends, family, even the person they brushed by on the street. It stains the heart, blooms like a flower on the water, near drowning as it passes the surface of the world and drops into the bucket of life and lives and living beyond. 

Molly did not fear pinpricks. He didn’t fear blood or bleeding or wounds on the backs of arms and ankles, sprinting ahead with swords drawn and teeth bared and tail lashing at the next unsuspecting victim to be stained. A pinprick? Child’s play. Molly was no innocent on the playground, no dirty-faced babe left in the dust by uncaring friends with a bleeding elbow and no mother to kiss it. A pinprick was a caress and Molly lived for the senses.

When the world fell out from under him, when Lorenzo’s voice echoed in his ears, when his friends’ screams died out in the emptiness and his body hit the ground, Molly felt none of it. Instead he felt the prick of death like a kiss on the lips, felt the tiny river start to bleed from his heart and wind through his organs and limbs and fall out across the world, to stain it with his lost presence and smear his smile onto the sun’s missing light. He wanted to lick it off his teeth.

Well, fuck you, too was his last conscious thought, the surface wish as vision faded, feeling evaporated, and his breath left his lungs. Then the pinprick bled and the world opened before him. His unconscious thoughts littered the world in the thousands. Yasha, the first would have been, the first drop of blood squeezed from his heart. The circus, as another, and family. And family would dovetail into the last faces he’d seen and cared around, as the blood stained his ribs. Caleb’s scruffy beard. Nott’s sticky claws. Beau’s indignant snort. More beyond, the needle driving deeper into Molly’s heart and drawing back red with life. Jester a source of joy, Fjord the voice of reason. The strange group he’d collided with when his former life collapsed around him, when reliable turned to deplorable, and coincidence became dependence.

Life. The river stopped cold and his blood froze in his veins.

Whoever he was, I’m not him. I don’t care.

Molly had no regrets about Lucien, never would never will don’t know don’t care get away get away get away this isn’t me is one of his final thoughts as the river finds its warmth again and steals the last edges of his soul clinging to miserable, vibrant, painful, terrifying, exuberant life. Two years is a cruelly short life. He did his best to fit all of life’s pleasures into it but what is pleasure in a life where he didn’t say ‘I love you’ enough? Molly left every town he knew better than it was but he only knew a dozen and remembered even fewer, half of the names he bothered with taken by the people screaming his name and clamoring to protect him and did Beau get away? She hadn’t had a chance to loosen up yet. So young and robbed of her ability to not take herself seriously. So young and pinpricked and bleeding and two years was not enough time, never enough time, fuck you too Lucien.

The blood curves over his torso and Molly doesn’t want a grave, oh Moonweaver, they’ll make him a grave won’t they? He crawled out of one he doesn’t want another don’t mark it don’t leave it don’t cry, he’s not someone worth crying over. Molly doesn’t want tears wasted on him. The needle digs deeper and his life drips down his legs, arms, past fingers and toes and seeps back to the earth he crawled from two years ago, two years two years two years what will they tell Yasha, how will she know, will she ever know.

Molly squeezed life like a ripe orange to drink its nectar and two years was not enough to fill his belly. How long? Five, ten, fifty? Never enough, it didn’t matter, two years fuck you too two years and that is not me I am not him but what if I wasn’t? Never him and more than two years and Yasha would never know, the Mighty Nein would never know, not an option, two years standing on earth he didn’t deserve with a life he didn’t earn, and now he pays it back with a needle and thread pulling his soul back where it belongs, belonged, a warm embrace to belong to. Fuck you, too. My family will find you. They’ll dig the needle in themselves. Enjoy being a prick while it lasts.

I wrote a little stream-of-consciousness thing for Molly. 

Warnings: death, obviously. also blood imagery. 

words: ~800

–

Death is a pinprick. It pierces the heart to bleed slow, rips out life in tiny imperceptible threads that leave them strung up and torn up and waiting for the end. It doesn’t matter how fast it is–the infinity of a moment stretches like a shadow at sunset, pulled to the horizon where the end is blurred and unreachable, beyond the grasp of reality and vanishing past the sky.

Life. The river stopped cold and his blood froze in his veins.

Whoever he was, I’m not him. I don’t care.

Molly had no regrets about Lucien, never would never will don’t know don’t care get away get away get away this isn’t me is one of his final thoughts as the river finds its warmth again and steals the last edges of his soul clinging to miserable, vibrant, painful, terrifying, exuberant life. Two years is a cruelly short life. He did his best to fit all of life’s pleasures into it but what is pleasure in a life where he didn’t say ‘I love you’ enough? Molly left every town he knew better than it was but he only knew a dozen and remembered even fewer, half of the names he bothered with taken by the people screaming his name and clamoring to protect him and did Beau get away? She hadn’t had a chance to loosen up yet. So young and robbed of her ability to not take herself seriously. So young and pinpricked and bleeding and two years was not enough time, never enough time, fuck you too Lucien.

The blood curves over his torso and Molly doesn’t want a grave, oh Moonweaver, they’ll make him a grave won’t they? He crawled out of one he doesn’t want another don’t mark it don’t leave it don’t cry, he’s not someone worth crying over. Molly doesn’t want tears wasted on him. The needle digs deeper and his life drips down his legs, arms, past fingers and toes and seeps back to the earth he crawled from two years ago, two years two years two years what will they tell Yasha, how will she know, will she ever know.

Molly squeezed life like a ripe orange to drink its nectar and two years was not enough to fill his belly. How long? Five, ten, fifty? Never enough, it didn’t matter, two years fuck you too two years and that is not me I am not him but what if I wasn’t? Never him and more than two years and Yasha would never know, the Mighty Nein would never know, not an option, two years standing on earth he didn’t deserve with a life he didn’t earn, and now he pays it back with a needle and thread pulling his soul back where it belongs, belonged, a warm embrace to belong to. Fuck you, too. My family will find you. They’ll dig the needle in themselves. Enjoy being a prick while it lasts.
trail.content:
I wrote a little stream-of-consciousness thing for Molly. 

Warnings: death, obviously. also blood imagery. 

words: ~800

–

Death is a pinprick. It pierces the heart to bleed slow, rips out life in tiny imperceptible threads that leave them strung up and torn up and waiting for the end. It doesn’t matter how fast it is–the infinity of a moment stretches like a shadow at sunset, pulled to the horizon where the end is blurred and unreachable, beyond the grasp of reality and vanishing past the sky.

It bleeds. Long beyond the point of death, it bleeds. One strike and the river runs pure down the bodies of friends, family, even the person they brushed by on the street. It stains the heart, blooms like a flower on the water, near drowning as it passes the surface of the world and drops into the bucket of life and lives and living beyond. 

Molly did not fear pinpricks. He didn’t fear blood or bleeding or wounds on the backs of arms and ankles, sprinting ahead with swords drawn and teeth bared and tail lashing at the next unsuspecting victim to be stained. A pinprick? Child’s play. Molly was no innocent on the playground, no dirty-faced babe left in the dust by uncaring friends with a bleeding elbow and no mother to kiss it. A pinprick was a caress and Molly lived for the senses.

When the world fell out from under him, when Lorenzo’s voice echoed in his ears, when his friends’ screams died out in the emptiness and his body hit the ground, Molly felt none of it. Instead he felt the prick of death like a kiss on the lips, felt the tiny river start to bleed from his heart and wind through his organs and limbs and fall out across the world, to stain it with his lost presence and smear his smile onto the sun’s missing light. He wanted to lick it off his teeth.

Well, fuck you, too was his last conscious thought, the surface wish as vision faded, feeling evaporated, and his breath left his lungs. Then the pinprick bled and the world opened before him. His unconscious thoughts littered the world in the thousands. Yasha, the first would have been, the first drop of blood squeezed from his heart. The circus, as another, and family. And family would dovetail into the last faces he’d seen and cared around, as the blood stained his ribs. Caleb’s scruffy beard. Nott’s sticky claws. Beau’s indignant snort. More beyond, the needle driving deeper into Molly’s heart and drawing back red with life. Jester a source of joy, Fjord the voice of reason. The strange group he’d collided with when his former life collapsed around him, when reliable turned to deplorable, and coincidence became dependence.

Life. The river stopped cold and his blood froze in his veins.

Whoever he was, I’m not him. I don’t care.

Molly had no regrets about Lucien, never would never will don’t know don’t care get away get away get away this isn’t me is one of his final thoughts as the river finds its warmth again and steals the last edges of his soul clinging to miserable, vibrant, painful, terrifying, exuberant life. Two years is a cruelly short life. He did his best to fit all of life’s pleasures into it but what is pleasure in a life where he didn’t say ‘I love you’ enough? Molly left every town he knew better than it was but he only knew a dozen and remembered even fewer, half of the names he bothered with taken by the people screaming his name and clamoring to protect him and did Beau get away? She hadn’t had a chance to loosen up yet. So young and robbed of her ability to not take herself seriously. So young and pinpricked and bleeding and two years was not enough time, never enough time, fuck you too Lucien.

The blood curves over his torso and Molly doesn’t want a grave, oh Moonweaver, they’ll make him a grave won’t they? He crawled out of one he doesn’t want another don’t mark it don’t leave it don’t cry, he’s not someone worth crying over. Molly doesn’t want tears wasted on him. The needle digs deeper and his life drips down his legs, arms, past fingers and toes and seeps back to the earth he crawled from two years ago, two years two years two years what will they tell Yasha, how will she know, will she ever know.

Molly squeezed life like a ripe orange to drink its nectar and two years was not enough to fill his belly. How long? Five, ten, fifty? Never enough, it didn’t matter, two years fuck you too two years and that is not me I am not him but what if I wasn’t? Never him and more than two years and Yasha would never know, the Mighty Nein would never know, not an option, two years standing on earth he didn’t deserve with a life he didn’t earn, and now he pays it back with a needle and thread pulling his soul back where it belongs, belonged, a warm embrace to belong to. Fuck you, too. My family will find you. They’ll dig the needle in themselves. Enjoy being a prick while it lasts.

–

It doesn’t matter how fast it is–the infinity of a moment stretches like a shadow at sunset, pulled to the horizon where the end is blurred and unreachable, beyond the grasp of reality and vanishing past the sky.

summary: Custom Leather Bracers available now at my etsy  It’s been a while since I put these up for sale but I figured, now that I’ve...
caption:
Custom Leather Bracers available now at my etsy

It’s been a while since I put these up for sale but I figured, now that I’ve got the time, I should actually advertise them.  So here we go.  I made a small selection of very nerdy custom leather bracers.  Yay!  They’re all hand tooled and hand stained and I think they turned out pretty nice.  If you’re interested in something kind of like this, I do offer custom work as well, any design you want.  Thanks for looking, have a great day.
